title: Question Forms
description: Learn how to ask for information using different types of questions in English.

grammarTheory.title: Wh-Questions
grammarTheory.contentHTML:
Wh-questions are used to ask for specific information. They cannot be answered with a simple 'yes' or 'no'. They begin with a question word.

Formula:

Wh-word + auxiliary verb + subject + main verb...?

Common Question Words:

  • What: Asks for information about things. (What is your name?)
  • When: Asks about time. (When does the meeting start?)
  • Where: Asks about a place. (Where do you live?)
  • Who: Asks about a person (subject). (Who opened the door?)
  • Whom: Asks about a person (object). (Whom did you see?)
  • Why: Asks for a reason. (Why are you late?)
  • Which: Asks about a choice. (Which color do you prefer?)
  • Whose: Asks about possession. (Whose bag is this?)
  • How: Asks about manner, condition, or quality. (How does this work?)

grammarTheory.title: Yes/No Questions
grammarTheory.contentHTML:
These questions can be answered with a simple 'yes' or 'no'. They begin with an auxiliary verb (like be, do, have) or a modal verb (like can, should, will).

Formula:

Auxiliary/Modal Verb + Subject + Main Verb...?

Examples:

  • Using Auxiliary Verbs:
    • Do you like coffee?
    • Have you finished your homework?
    • Is she your sister?
  • Using Modal Verbs:
    • Can you help me with this?
    • Should I bring my laptop?
    • Will they arrive on time?

grammarTheory.title: Choice Questions
grammarTheory.contentHTML:
Choice questions offer a choice between two or more options. They use the word 'or' to separate the choices.

Examples:

  • Do you want tea or coffee?
  • Which do you like more, the book or the movie?

grammarTheory.title: Tag Questions
grammarTheory.contentHTML:
A tag question is a small question added to the end of a statement. We use them to confirm information or to encourage a reply.

The Rule: If the main statement is positive, the tag is negative. If the main statement is negative, the tag is positive.

Formula:

Statement, auxiliary/modal verb (+ not) + pronoun?

Examples:

  • Positive Statement, Negative Tag:
    She is your sister, isn't she?
  • Negative Statement, Positive Tag:
    You donâ€™t like tea, do you?

grammarTheory.title: Negative Questions
grammarTheory.contentHTML:
Negative questions usually start with a negative form of an auxiliary or modal verb (e.g., Don't, Isn't, Can't). They are used to express surprise, or to check something you believe is true.

Examples:

  • Expressing Surprise:
    Don't you like coffee? I thought everyone did!
  • Confirming a Belief:
    Didn't he tell you about the meeting? I'm sure he did.

grammarTheory.title: Indirect Questions
grammarTheory.contentHTML:
Indirect questions are a more polite way to ask for information. They are often part of a longer sentence, starting with phrases like 'Could you tell me...' or 'I wonder...'.

Important: The word order in the question part is like a normal statement (subject before verb), not an inverted question.

Examples:

  • Direct Question: Where is the station?
  • Indirect Question: Could you tell me where the station is?

  • Direct Question: What time does the bank open?
  • Indirect Question: Do you know what time the bank opens?

grammarQuestions.prompt: He works in the marketing department, ___?
grammarQuestions.explanation: The statement 'He works' is positive (Present Simple), so the tag question must be negative using the auxiliary verb 'do' -> 'doesn't he'.

options.text: I'd like to know how much does this cost.
I'd like to know how much this costs.
I'd like to know how much this does cost.

grammarQuestions.explanation: In an indirect question, the word order is like a statement (subject + verb). The auxiliary 'does' is not needed, and the '-s' is added to the main verb 'cost'.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Which of these question words can be used to ask about time?
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'When' directly asks about a point in time. 'What time' is a common phrase to ask for a specific time on the clock.
